title: Chinese Government awards scholarships to 31 DRC students
description: On August 10, 2011, the Chinese Embassy held a farewell party for the 31 Congolese recipients of the 2011-2012 Chinese Government Scholarship. The 31 freshmen will study in China for the 2011-2012 school year as part of the scholarship. The value of the scholarships and their nature are unclear.

title: Chinese Government donates audio-visual equipment and more than 1,000 books to DRC’s National Cultural Center
description: On May 24, 2011, the Chinese Embassy granted audio-visual equipment and more than 1,000 books to the National Cultural Center in Democratic Republic of Congo. This donation was intended to help the Congolese National Cultural Center promote Chinese culture. The value of the donation and the exact equipment donated is unknown. This project is completed.

title: CDB provides loan to Orange RDC to pay for ZTE’s services in 2011 (Linked to Project ID#382 and #60113)
description: On December 14, 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a RMB 80 million ($9,664,765.67) concessional loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The proceeds of loan, which is captured via Project ID#382, were used to support the creation of joint venture between ZTE and the Congolese Office of Post Telecommunications (OCPT) in Kinshasa, called Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) or Congo-China Telecom S.A.R.L. (CCT) (Chinese name: 刚中电讯有限公司). ZTE held a 51% equity stake in the joint venture, and OCPT held a 49% equity stake. Most of the loan proceeds were used to be used by the borrower to acquire equipment from ZTE and thereby build CCT’s telecommunications network in the DRC.   According to the Aid Management Platform (AMP) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the loan achieved a 100% disbursement rate ($9,665,149.43 out of $9,664,765.67). CCT launched GSM-900/1800 services on December 31, 2001 in Katanga in the east of the country. It subsequently rolled out services to Kinshasa, Bas-Congo, Bandundu and the two provinces of Kasai, giving it coverage in 40 cities. The CCT network, at the time, had a capacity for 150,000 customers, with a single switch in Kinshasa, and it used a Belgacom earth station for its international gateway.   Then, on March 11, 2006, ZTE Corporation signed a sales contract and a service contract with Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) worth $123 million. On June 29, 2007, the China Development Bank (as arranger, initial lender and facility agent) signed the Phase I and Phase II loan facility agreements with CCT (as borrower). The aggregate loan amount was $105 million (covering Phase I with $63 million and Phase II with $42 million). The proceeds of the loan, which is captured via Project ID#60113, were to be used to finance CCT’s payments to ZTE Corporation worth 85% of the cost of the 2006 sales and service contract. The 2007 loan was guaranteed by the ZTE Corporation's 51% equity interest (see Project ID#383) in Congo-Chine Télécom (CCT). The Ministry of State-owned Enterprises of Congo (Kinshasa) provided a counter-guarantee by pledging its 25% equity interest in CCT. The loan was also secured with (i.e. collateralized against) fixed assets purchased by the borrower with the loan proceeds.   Then, on October 20, 2011, France Telecom-Orange (FT-Orange) acquired a 100% ownership stake in CCT  (the majority of which was assumed debt), buying the 51% ownership stake held by the ZTE Corporation and the 49% ownership stake held the Congolese State. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with ZTE Corporation, FT-Orange agreed to pay $10 million (EUR 7 million) to the Chinese equipment manufacturer for its 51% stake in CCT. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (after a call for tenders), FT-Orange agreed to pay $7 million (EUR 5 million) to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for its 49% stake in CCT.  CCT was renamed ‘Orange RDC’ and the Orange brand was introduced to the DRC on December 6, 2012. As part of the October 2011 acquisition, Orange RDC (formerly Congo Chine Télécoms or CCT) signed a $276,250,000 loan agreement with China Development Bank (captured via Project ID#95662). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to repay the outstanding (assumed) debts of CCT and to expand CCT’s existing telecommunications network. In the last quarter of 2011, FT-Orange also announced that ZTE Corporation would provide it with infrastructure and services as a preferred supplier, drawing upon ‘strategic financing support’ from China Development Bank. Following the October 2011 acquisition, FT-Orange invested CDF 87.4 billion ($89.6 million) to expand and enhance CCT’s telecommunications network, including an upgrade to 3G. Orange RDC had 1.8 million mobile customers as of December 2012. By the end of 2014, Orange RDC had 14.3 million mobile customers.
staff_comments: 1. The face value of the loan that CDB issued to Orange RDC was $276,250,000. However, some (unknown) portion of the proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to repay the outstanding (assumed) debts of CCT. For the time being, AIdData has estimated the new and additional debt issued through the 2011 loan as $171,250,000 (the difference between the face value of the 2007 CDB loan and the face value of the 2011 CDB loan, or $276,250,000 minus $105,000,000).2. It is unknown if the 2011 CDB loan was collateralized. However, for the time being, AidData assumes that it was since the 2007 CDB loan was collateralized.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
CDB provides loan to Orange RDC to pay for ZTE’s services in 2011 (Linked to Project ID#382 and #60113)

# Description
On December 14, 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a RMB 80 million ($9,664,765.67) concessional loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The proceeds of loan, which is captured via Project ID#382, were used to support the creation of joint venture between ZTE and the Congolese Office of Post Telecommunications (OCPT) in Kinshasa, called Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) or Congo-China Telecom S.A.R.L. (CCT) (Chinese name: 刚中电讯有限公司). ZTE held a 51% equity stake in the joint venture, and OCPT held a 49% equity stake. Most of the loan proceeds were used to be used by the borrower to acquire equipment from ZTE and thereby build CCT’s telecommunications network in the DRC.   According to the Aid Management Platform (AMP) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the loan achieved a 100% disbursement rate ($9,665,149.43 out of $9,664,765.67). CCT launched GSM-900/1800 services on December 31, 2001 in Katanga in the east of the country. It subsequently rolled out services to Kinshasa, Bas-Congo, Bandundu and the two provinces of Kasai, giving it coverage in 40 cities. The CCT network, at the time, had a capacity for 150,000 customers, with a single switch in Kinshasa, and it used a Belgacom earth station for its international gateway.   Then, on March 11, 2006, ZTE Corporation signed a sales contract and a service contract with Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) worth $123 million. On June 29, 2007, the China Development Bank (as arranger, initial lender and facility agent) signed the Phase I and Phase II loan facility agreements with CCT (as borrower). The aggregate loan amount was $105 million (covering Phase I with $63 million and Phase II with $42 million). The proceeds of the loan, which is captured via Project ID#60113, were to be used to finance CCT’s payments to ZTE Corporation worth 85% of the cost of the 2006 sales and service contract. The 2007 loan was guaranteed by the ZTE Corporation's 51% equity interest (see Project ID#383) in Congo-Chine Télécom (CCT). The Ministry of State-owned Enterprises of Congo (Kinshasa) provided a counter-guarantee by pledging its 25% equity interest in CCT. The loan was also secured with (i.e. collateralized against) fixed assets purchased by the borrower with the loan proceeds.   Then, on October 20, 2011, France Telecom-Orange (FT-Orange) acquired a 100% ownership stake in CCT  (the majority of which was assumed debt), buying the 51% ownership stake held by the ZTE Corporation and the 49% ownership stake held the Congolese State. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with ZTE Corporation, FT-Orange agreed to pay $10 million (EUR 7 million) to the Chinese equipment manufacturer for its 51% stake in CCT. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (after a call for tenders), FT-Orange agreed to pay $7 million (EUR 5 million) to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for its 49% stake in CCT.  CCT was renamed ‘Orange RDC’ and the Orange brand was introduced to the DRC on December 6, 2012. As part of the October 2011 acquisition, Orange RDC (formerly Congo Chine Télécoms or CCT) signed a $276,250,000 loan agreement with China Development Bank (captured via Project ID#95662). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to repay the outstanding (assumed) debts of CCT and to expand CCT’s existing telecommunications network. In the last quarter of 2011, FT-Orange also announced that ZTE Corporation would provide it with infrastructure and services as a preferred supplier, drawing upon ‘strategic financing support’ from China Development Bank. Following the October 2011 acquisition, FT-Orange invested CDF 87.4 billion ($89.6 million) to expand and enhance CCT’s telecommunications network, including an upgrade to 3G. Orange RDC had 1.8 million mobile customers as of December 2012. By the end of 2014, Orange RDC had 14.3 million mobile customers.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Telecommunications network development, GSM services, 3G upgrade, mobile customer expansion

title: Chinese Government provides 1,720 cartons of medicines and vitamins following the 2011-2012 East Africa drought
description: Between July 2011 and mid-2012, a severe drought affected the entire East African region, including Djibouti. On November 9 and 16, 2011, the Chinese Ambassador and the Djibouti Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed an exchange of letters in which China pledged to donate 1,720 cartons of medicines and vitamins to drought-stricken areas in Djibouti. This donation was officially delivered on August 5, 2012 to the Djibouti Secretary-General of the Ministry of Health. The 1,720 cartons carried streptomycin, an anti-TB drug and vitamin B complex.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides 1,720 cartons of medicines and vitamins following the 2011-2012 East Africa drought

# Description
Between July 2011 and mid-2012, a severe drought affected the entire East African region, including Djibouti. On November 9 and 16, 2011, the Chinese Ambassador and the Djibouti Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed an exchange of letters in which China pledged to donate 1,720 cartons of medicines and vitamins to drought-stricken areas in Djibouti. This donation was officially delivered on August 5, 2012 to the Djibouti Secretary-General of the Ministry of Health. The 1,720 cartons carried streptomycin, an anti-TB drug and vitamin B complex.
justification: Project involves humanitarian medical aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medicines and vitamins for drought relief, healthcare focus

title: 16th medical team dispatched to General Peltier Hospital in Djibouti
description: On 8 March, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Djibouti signed an agreement to dispatch the 16th medical team to work in Djibouti. The 14-member team arrived in Djibouti on 1 April 2012. They served at General Peltier Hospital (l’Hôpital Général Peltier) until the end of 2013.  Since 1981, the Chinese Government has sent 19 medical teams to Djibouti.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
16th medical team dispatched to General Peltier Hospital in Djibouti

# Description
On 8 March, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Djibouti signed an agreement to dispatch the 16th medical team to work in Djibouti. The 14-member team arrived in Djibouti on 1 April 2012. They served at General Peltier Hospital (l’Hôpital Général Peltier) until the end of 2013.  Since 1981, the Chinese Government has sent 19 medical teams to Djibouti.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team dispatch to hospital, healthcare focus

title: China provides grant to the Djibouti Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the provision of vehicles and office supplies
description: On 1 June 2011, the Chinese government held a handover ceremony to donate vehicles and office supplies to the Djibouti Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  The Chinese Ambassador to Djibouti, Zhang Guoqing, and Djibouti's Minister of International Cooperation, Minister Ahmad Ali Silai, attended the ceremony and signed the transfer certificate of the donation on behalf of both governments. According to the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, the supplies included a pickup truck, a bus, and office supplies such as computers and printers. The value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China provides grant to the Djibouti Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the provision of vehicles and office supplies

# Description
On 1 June 2011, the Chinese government held a handover ceremony to donate vehicles and office supplies to the Djibouti Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  The Chinese Ambassador to Djibouti, Zhang Guoqing, and Djibouti's Minister of International Cooperation, Minister Ahmad Ali Silai, attended the ceremony and signed the transfer certificate of the donation on behalf of both governments. According to the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, the supplies included a pickup truck, a bus, and office supplies such as computers and printers. The value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of vehicles and office supplies to government ministry, with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of pickup truck, bus, computers, and printers to Ministry of Foreign Affairs

title: Chinese government donates medicine and medical equipment to General Peltier Hospital in December 2011
description: On 11 December 2011, the Chinese government held a ceremony to officially hand over a batch of medicines and medical equipment to General Peltier Hospital (吉贝尔蒂医院) in Djibouti. This donation is part of a Chinese effort to improve Djibouti's healthcare industry. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.

title: China grants funds for a Solar Street Light Project in Djibouti
description: On 7 and 8 December 2011, the Chinese Ambassador and Djibouti Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed an exchange of letters for the Solar Street Light Project. The Chinese government financed this project with a grant of an unknown value.   On 10 April 2012, ZTE Corporation signed the implementation contract of China-aided solar street lighting project in Djibouti. Work plans involved the installation of 300 solar power street lights in two areas of Djibouti City. The purpose of this project was to protect the personal and property safety of the Djiboutian people as well as provide support for their development of green energy. The official handover ceremony took place on 18 November 2013.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China grants funds for a Solar Street Light Project in Djibouti

# Description
On 7 and 8 December 2011, the Chinese Ambassador and Djibouti Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed an exchange of letters for the Solar Street Light Project. The Chinese government financed this project with a grant of an unknown value.   On 10 April 2012, ZTE Corporation signed the implementation contract of China-aided solar street lighting project in Djibouti. Work plans involved the installation of 300 solar power street lights in two areas of Djibouti City. The purpose of this project was to protect the personal and property safety of the Djiboutian people as well as provide support for their development of green energy. The official handover ceremony took place on 18 November 2013.
justification: Primary purpose is solar-powered street lighting with explicit green energy development support
evidence: Installation of 300 solar power street lights, explicit mention of green energy development support
